Transcription for 2156611

Today is Thursday June the 23rd. My name is Jill Willie and I'm here today speaking with
Roy Evans at his home in Ryder, home with an absolutely beautiful view. Well Roy, thanks
very much for agreeing to talk to me. First of all, can we start by just asking your year
of birth please?
Right, that's fine. Okay, now you've lived and worked in Ryder all your life. Can you
start off with your early life, where you were born?
I was the first child to be born in Cai Glass when they were elected them as they were finishing
them. So I was born there in 1948 with my brothers, you know, and we had a happy time there. And
the whole row, there's loads of us children up there and we had some great fun like, isn't
it? Yeah.
Were you able to play in the streets then? Was it safe to play on the road?
Oh yes, there's, outside our house in Cai Glass we lived in number three. There was
a lamppost there and there was another one up by my uncle in number 11 Cai Glass. And
we found out in the winter, if we hit the lamppost with a big stone, we'd knock the
light off so we could play hide and seek. And then every Saturday morning, Mr Williams,
who worked for the electricity board, would be coming up with his ladder to go up to put
the timer back on the clock or the lights. And we'd do the same thing again.
And did he ever catch on?
No, no, I don't think so, no. When we were very young, one of the highlights Saturday
morning, Mr Williams, they'd come up, the bread men, two brothers in red at the time,
he'd come up with his horse and cart with the bread. And the bread, he had a canvas
sheet on the back of the trailer and the bread was piping hot and mum always had a round
loaf with rings on it. So we'd take that in straight for mum and she'd cut the crust
off both ends, put butter on it for my brother and myself. That was one of the treats on
the Saturday.
That was your reward for delivering the bread?
Yes, yes.
Wonderful.
And then do we add another man come up, Bimmy I think, the milkman, he used to come up a
glass with his milk flukes again, horse and cart. I can remember them, days well.
Things have certainly changed.
Oh, they have, yeah.
You wouldn't expect to see that sort of delivery anymore.
What other families lived in Kiglass near you?
Number one was, her first husband died, so there were Joneses and Carraddocks then, and
there was a family of ten between the two, two families. And then number two there was
Missy Sharp when I was younger. We were number three. And number four was Mr. Watkins, Margaret
Watkins, she was in the Beauty Queen contest and her father worked for the council and
he was one of them. He used to go round with a bit of a truck with two bins on to sweep
the roads. And then next to him there was Jill Williams, his home, Quentin Davis, and
he was a character. And the next one then to him was Tom Jones, Dai Jones is Auntie's
father, we call him Dai Spanner, and they had a sister as well. And the next lot to
him was Eddie Futcher and he was a character. Because he didn't carry glass at the time.
We had massive gardens at the back because the road by the British Leeds, it was only
enough for one car, so you can imagine how big the gardens were. And Eddie was no gardener,
so the council wrote to him to tell him to tidy his garden up. And he replied back to
him in the letter and said, when I applied for a council house, I expected a council
house, not a homestead. Which was just like him. The next lot to him was the Bowenzes,
they were a very big family again. There was a big family of eight or nine there. And
then I don't know, there was another one, Bacchie Kinsley, he worked on the post but
he did cobbling as well. He had a little shop down there opposite the bay. And who was the
next one? Oh it was the next one was Jane Arborer's house, she lived there with her
And then there was my uncle Bill was number 11, he was a bit of a character. And then
number 12 was the Murphy's. And I always remember when we were a lot younger, we used to call
other boys here at Green Gardens, and some of that were boys, they used to call them
the Bay Boys because they always went drinking in the bay. And you'll be guaranteed Saturday
night they start at number 12 and jump the hedges. And my father had a big privet hedge
with a peak on it. And in the morning a big big dense in it and the Bay Boys called it
Beeches Brook because nobody made it. So you know we had a lot of, we made our own fun
up there then, like isn't it? Not damaged nothing but just good fun, you'll have your
gates taken off the hinges and things like that. So we had a happy childhood there.
Well he certainly did, we could almost write a book about Kiglass itself couldn't we?
Oh yes. Yes. Oh wonderful. And then school days Roy, which schools did you go to in this
town? Cuntida School, the other side there, but then Mrs Lloyd was headmistress and we
had to recite Cuntida, we used to say C W M D A U D D W R Cuntida. And my wife said
why couldn't you learn something like that even when you were in school all the time?
And after that Raider School. That was a good time there, like isn't there? A wonderful
headmaster, I can't think what his name was now. Mr Price. Mr Price, he was a good headmaster.
And then we went to the big school, Secondary Modern, which we thought was massive. We
had a lot of fun up there but I think the most that was in the school was ninety odd
then, you know we had a lot of fun and farm children came, most of them come to Brindale
School. We used to call the ones who went to Landrinders Grammar School county cabbage.
Alright. And what are your memories of Bryn Tyrion? Did you enjoy sport there Roy? Oh
yes I loved sport, yeah it was good, good all round really, like I enjoyed it up there.
Were you in the football team? Yes I played for Radisher Schools, Wynn Lloyd and myself
and Pinchy, yeah. We hardly won a game. Taking part that counts. And your school subjects
then, did you have any favourites? I quite like maths, I hope that's a spell in, I still
am a bit like isn't it, you know. My wife always says she thinks I was a little bit
dyslectic the way I used to pronounce things. She said of course today they pick it up,
you know. No we had happy times eh. I didn't like being in the choir. Friday was choir
day or gardening so we all went gardening instead of being in the choir. And where did
you do the gardening Roy? Well they did start up, they used to be up where Ainsley Richards
lives now, up behind there. They started to dig some of the ground up. Now that I know
a bit about gardening nothing grew there much because there was trees everywhere and it
took everything out of the soil. And when we were in the garden digging it we used to
find bullets because the army were billeted up there during the war and they used to go
practising in the field behind. They were all dads most of them like isn't they. So
did you have a lot of time trying to find all these bullet holes? No it's just that
when we were digging the garden and we were picking them up like isn't it. Of course
we didn't know if they were alive or dead then like isn't it. And another time we started
to be, it seems dull today but on a Friday afternoon we used to go up to where the car
park is now, that was part of the big old house then before it was pulled down. And
we started to dig down and clear the old cellar out which was there with stones and
we were tipping them in the wood because we were going to make a swimming pool there.
So we were all up there every Friday for an hour for a long time doing it. And once we
dug it out after they built the one that was in the school then, the local people collected
the money for it. So they filled the cellar up after. And I think that was my training
for being in the building site lifting the stones up. Very good start. Good transition
from school into the building trade. So could we talk a little bit about that now, how it
all started and where you worked in building trade. It was in the Red area wasn't it?
I started my time with Bernard Lloyd. In those days in school we didn't have what you call
a careers officer coming round much. My father said to me one day when I was ready to leave
school, I got you a job he said, he doesn't want any carpet but he could do with a mason
and that was my starting life. So he'd asked Bernard Lloyd, so I started with Bernard then.
We never went to college then. Bernard said if you go to college you'll swallow the union
book. It can teach you more on site which you could like you know. And when I started
I was mixing cement because I was told how can you tell a labourer how to mix cement
if you can't do it yourself. That was the upbringing you know. And as I said King Morgan
was very good to me and Dick Mitten was very good. And the Carpenter's were very good,
they were very skilled carpenters. John Lloyd, Bill Johnson and of course Derek Cadwallagh,
Ralph Oakley they were all good tradesmen then. And Bernard Lloyd now, did he have his
own building firm? Because I think he took on a lot of apprentices. Yeah Bernard he was
the main builder in town here. The only other builder at the time was Tom Morgan and Tom
only had his brother Idris and two other boys but Bernard had the majority. I think there
was 20 working for Bernard when I started. And where did you work? I believe you mentioned
the Therrow estate. We used to go up there patching the barns up round town putting slates
and rows all manner of little jobs like wasn't it you know. You'd be pushing it up a street
with a wheelbarrow or a truck with a ladder on. And my friend Dick was telling me one
day, Dick I learnt my apprenticeship with, the bloke laboring for him then was called
Evan, this was Jill Williams' grandfather. And Dick would say we'd be pushing the wheelbarrow
up by the police station pitch. And he used to say to Dick, take over, this was half past
seven quarter to eight in the morning, take over Yonge. And he said, so Dick could get
the wheelbarrow to go on, Evan would go in behind the back of the Coombe tither arms
coming out wiping his face and he said, that feels better. He'd been in for a pint that
time of the morning. And when they were never without a good bucket because in those days
the ashes were put in buckets put outside the houses because they were hot. If we had
a hole in our bucket they'd tip the ashes into the bucket with a hole and take the good
bucket. They had it all worked out by the sounds of things, my word. And you've been
in the building trade all your working life then? Yes, yes. Of particular interest is
the bread oven I believe, Dick Mitten of whom you've been speaking, told you a little bit
about this and how to construct one. Could you give me any info on that? I haven't built
the bread oven myself but I think Dick might have done one and he was telling me what they
used to do. He said, I think you had roughly a two foot diameter hole, ring I should say,
and then you put a brick upright which is nine inches and then a brick on top which
made it 13 inches and you go round like that and build the bread oven door in. And when
that's set you filled it all up with sand and you mounted the top like an oval shape
and then you bricked over the top of it and when that's set it was all done in line more
to them but the joints were very very tight because they didn't want the fire to break
it up. And once that's set you open the bread oven door and pull the sand out so it was
still formed all then as a little place like in there. They used to put all the all the
bracken and sticks in the fire, get it all warm and then pull it out so the fire bricks
were warm and then you can just push the bread in. And would these be used in commercial
bakeries or? No, mostly in old farm houses, things like that. Where my brother lives now,
I did some work up there, repaired some work and there was a massive bread oven up there
that was a very big one and that did the baking for the estate for the whole area. And where is
that? That's up in Llandinan. And I think we did some work years and years ago for Elwyn at the
Lyon Hotel. Elwyn asked Dick was there a do you think there's a fire grate, an old-fashioned fire
grate? And Dick said well yes, he said if it's an eight foot opening and about that four foot
return it's surely a big grate. So Elwyn and William, they had I don't know how many tonnes
of stone out from there and we we did it up the oak beam and all but in the corner if I
I haven't been in there for years now in the corner there's a baking oven and I'm sure that's one is
dead out of stone and you don't often see a baked bread oven dead out of stone but see the lion is
that old I suppose he didn't have fire bricks in them days you know so I'm gonna go one day into
the lion to see was I right was it a stone one I think back of my mind it was like you know.
Can you tell me exactly where the lion is in in Raerder Roy? It's
